title: Climate activists, cops injured, 40 arrests
text:
A young climate protester was taken to hospital after being injured by a police horse during the volatile blockade.

Two people were also arrested for animal cruelty after assaulting a police horse.

Camila Serra, 23, was taken to the Alfred Hospital in a stable condition having suffered a leg injury during Tuesday's protest at the Melbourne Convention and Exhibition Centre.

Another protester said he saw her fall backwards after being struck by the horse.

"The horses shouldn't be here as they get extremely nervous and have hurt a woman," Callum, who did not want to give his surname, said.

Tensions raised each time delegates tried to enter the conference, with many of the protesters booing. Some attendees turned away when confronted.

Protesters estimate more than 45 people were arrested.

"Most of the people arrested have been released with summary offences," Rohan, a legal guide from the protest, said.

Four police officers suffered injuries including a dislocated finger and minor head injuries. Some were taken to hospital for treatment.

Officers used capsicum spray to subdue protesters and were seen placing people in headlocks and pushing them to the ground. Footage showed one woman being pulled by her hair.

"Police have been incredibly aggressive but that isn't unexpected. There's a lack of communication on their side," protest organiser Emma Black said.

"I, for instance, have been hit by a baton."

Four police officers suffered injuries including a dislocated finger and minor head injuries.

Ms Black said they would continue to disrupt the conference despite the violence.

On Tuesday afternoon the group will be joined by Victorian Greens leader Samantha Ratnam, and federal Greens MP Adam Bandt will attend on Wednesday.

Conference organisers say the protest action is based on misconceptions about the mining industry.

Advertisement

They say the conference will consider the importance of battery minerals, used in the emerging electric car market, and the growing importance of ethical investment for resource companies, they said.

Premier Daniel Andrews said while protesting was a democratic right, violence is not acceptable.

"That's a difficult balance sometimes, but I'm confident Victoria Police can find that balance," he told reporters.

AAP
description: Hundreds of activists linked to numerous groups gathered outside the Melbourne convention centre in an effort to stop delegates attending the International Mining and Resources Conference.
